An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.
Does the concept of a/an Element of a Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To define an A-module, we need to specify that it is an abelian group M, and there is an operation A x M -> M. This operation involves elements from the set A and the set M. The definition of an A-module explicitly uses the concept of elements (a, b from A and x, y from M) to describe the properties of the operation. Therefore, the concept of an element of a set is fundamental in describing what it means for something to be an A-module. Without understanding what an element of a set is, we cannot properly define the operations or the axioms of an A-module, as these operations are defined in terms of elements of the sets A and M.
